Abby Norman
Wrote a medical mystery memoir for Nation Books. I’m an associate science editor @ Futurism & host of Let Me Google That @ Anchor.fm | Lit agent: Tisse Takagi
Jun 16, 2016

Last night’s filibuster on gun control ended after nearly 15 hours with Connecticut Senator Chris Murphy delivering a speech that broke my heart. Background: my younger brother, Caleb, has autism. His 1–1 aid, Nancy, has been in his life since he was just a wee thing. Even after he graduated she has stayed in his life because she’s a literal angel.

So, when Sen. Murphy ended by telling the story of a young boy with autism who was murdered at Sandy Hook; how his aid, Anne Marie Murphy, held him in his final moments before they both died — I lost it. I could no longer keep down the mounting feelings of anguish that I swallow whenever mass shootings happen in this country. I didn’t just cry, I got angry.

Up until now, every shooting that happens in this country, I’ve felt a little more desensitized. I gape in horror at the live news coverage but there’s a part of me that has just gone completely numb to the suffering. It happens far too much, there is no time to recover from the mourning of the last before the next one happens.

This ongoing argument is not about gun ownership; it’s much broader than that. It’s about our entire culture. If you become defensive at this issue because you think someone is trying to take your gun away, then shut you’re fucking ridiculous mouth. This is not about that. Gun Control legislation is trying to make sure that people who own guns are owning them for reasonable, sound-of-mind reasons.

Like what, you ask?

If you collect them, that’s cool. I have friends who are hobbyists, and their collections are remarkable.

If you target shoot or skeet shoot, great, I’ve done it! I’m terrible at it, but it’s a lot of fucking fun.

If you are a hunter —especially in Maine, where I’m from, — then I can almost guarantee that you are among some of the most well-educated and well self-regulated gun owners in our state; probably in our nation. You know how to safely handle a firearm. You clean it and care for it, you take pride in it. You teach your children SAFETY FIRST AND ALWAYS. You look out for those in your hunting teams, you keep one another safe. Because a gun, no matter what, is a weapon capable of taking a life. The hunters I know know this. They never forget for a moment how powerful a gun is.

And accidents happen. I have known far too many young people who have died this way. When young people are not taught gun safety, when they feel invincible, terrible things happen. Stupid, awful, terrible things happen.

Gun control is kind of about that. It’s also, more specifically, about making sure that when this country manufactures and sells guns, it is accountable for who ends up owning them. So much of what is being asked is simply common sense: if you are on a no-fly list, you should not be able to buy a gun. Background checks are not about taking guns away from people who obtained them lawfully, they’re about making sure that people who may intend to use them unlawfully do not get to obtain them.

I have many friends who own guns for self defense. I have lived in homes where guns were kept in case of a break-in. In Maine especially, many of us grew up in very rural areas. If someone had thought to break into our house in the night, no amount of screaming would have helped us. If we had called 911, the town police would have taken too long to get there because we lived out in the fucking boonies. Whether your family had handguns on their nightstand, a rifle behind the door or a fucking longsword — yeah, chances are you had some kind of mechanism of defense if you lived ten miles outta town with no neighbors. I mean shit, sometimes it wasn’t even PEOPLE breaking in. Sometimes it was LEGIT BEARS.

Having a gun, for many families, was absolutely a protective measure. BUT EVERY SINGLE ONE OF THOSE FAMILIES I KNEW PRAYED THAT THEY WOULD NEVER. HAVE. TO. USE. THAT. GUN. There wasn’t this sense of bravado, they didn’t brag. A lot of them kept them extremely well-hidden, their children may not have even known there were guns in the house to begin with. These people didn’t have guns so they could exploit the Second Amendment on every fucking breath; they had guns because the were extremely educated on how to keep, use, and protect that firearm.

And if, at some point, they were in danger, they wanted to have some kind of way to protect their family. BUT THEY WERE NOT VIGILANTES. Most of these people, if asked, would have said that they would not shoot to kill — it was just to buy them some time so that they could escape, or the police could arrive — THESE PEOPLE DID NOT DREAM OF BECOMING MURDERERS.

But what you have to understand is that there are also people who DO have these dreams. And because of how incredibly easy it is to obtain a gun in this country, they are able to achieve this dream in living color, while we all watch helplessly. We say they were terrorists or mentally ill. Sometimes they are. And that begs the question: then why the hell did the American people, who have a palpable distrust of both of these groups, sell them a god damn firearm?

America has to have some accountability. Those who make the rules about selling guns in this country have to understand that every single time a movie theater or a church or a nightclub or FUCKING ELEMENTARY SCHOOL gets shot-up that THEY had a hand in it.

Every single time this happens we say, “Oh, he was mentally unstable, he had terrorist ties, he was a disgruntled employee with a violent past,” then those who sell guns, those who manufacture guns and those who put laws in place around guns need to say: THEN WHY. DID HE. HAVE. A. GUN.

The answer is extremely easy: Wal-Mart, which will sell you very reasonably priced guns, has tougher background check policies than the federal government requires.

JUST LET THAT SINK IN: A behemoth company like Wal-Mart, which has been notoriously terrible about most everything, will not sell you a gun without a CLEARED background check.

So fine, okay. You want a gun but you won’t pass a background check? Go to one of the innumerable mom-and-pop gun shops that doesn’t have to abide by regulations — because there ARE no strict federal regulations. Go buy one from a private dealer, for cash, in the parking lot of your local department store. HELL you can buy one online if you want to — put “buy a gun” into Google and get 34,200,000 results back.

After this speech from Sen. Murphy I suddenly found all of the rage and sadness that I had not felt before begin to bubble up to the surface. This story was just too close to home for me, and the truth is, so was what happened in Orlando. And it should be too close to home for ALL of you.

Because at this point, there isn’t one person left in this country who can look at these shooting and not think, “That could have been us,” — and just wait, at the rate we’re going, we’ve already had 182 mass shootings in this country this year. You very well might be next.

The next time someone walks into a movie theater, it might be your family in there. The next time someone enacts a hate crime in a church, it might be YOUR church. The next time someone shoots up an elementary school, it might be YOUR kids that perish. The next time someone takes the lives of people in the LGBTQ community, it might be your friends, or your kids, or people that you didn’t know were part of that community until they died because they were TOO AFRAID TO COME OUT.

We have to make these horrific events personal. We have all become too desensitized to the violence — we aren’t afraid anymore, and that’s the worst thing that could happen. We constantly put distance between ourselves and these tragedies, we say things like, “it didn’t affect me, I have no right to grieve” — and that’s a really convenient way to say, “I’m not obligated to feel anything about this because it didn’t directly influence my life.”

Or worse, you say that you’ll “pray for” these families. Look, I want you to pray — but pray for yourself that you will have the strength to DO something about this. If you want to honor those who we have lost, praying for their souls isn’t going to yield very much except making YOU feel better.

Honor their LIVES by donating blood, by writing or calling your senator, by being vocally opposed to this culture where we prioritize an amendment written by racists 200 years ago who had rudimentary guns that used flintlock for fuck’s sake!

Our founding fathers weren’t carrying around AR-15s, you fucking assholes.

PLEASE TELL ME WHY THE FUCK YOU EVEN NEED TO OWN AN AR-15? It’s one thing if you have it for looks, and it’s displayed in some ornate gun case as part of your collection, and it’s never loaded. Like cool, that’s dope.

BUT WHY. THE FUCK. DO YOU HAVE ONE. LOCKED AND LOADED. NEXT TO YOUR BED. Who the FUCK did you piss off that you feel like you need a motherfucking MILITARY RIFLE that can shoot — *you know what, fuck it, I’ve revised this bit based on a million different internet things and someone always comments on this piece saying I’m wrong so here’s a few screenshots you can go bitch out the sources, okay? Cool. Here’s the AR-15 specs. Whatever.

If you are expecting an entire mob of people to break into your house and try to kill you, then you need to really revaluate your life choices. If you actually BELIEVE that you need to own a gun like this, the gun is not the most dangerous thing about the situation: you are.
